text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Kuwait's press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The value of Kuwait's state-owned electricty sector is estimated at about 2.2 billion dinars ($7 billion). The government has presented parliament with a draft law for the privatisation of heavily-subsidised utilities which officials hope will be approved later this year.

- Some 4,500 people, mainly Kuwaitis, will on Tuesday receive first compensation payments for some of the damages resulting from the 1990-91 Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. The 1991 Gulf War reparations fund, set up by Security Council to assess damages, has received more than $220 billion in claims from individuals, companies and governments.
- Washington is believed to have a military plan to topple Gulf War foe Iraq's President Saddam Hussein.

- Kuwait's Emir Sheikh Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah telephones Crown Prince and Prime Minister Sheikh Saad al-Abdulla al-Sabah in London. Sheikh Saad flew to Britain last month after undergoing a colon surgery in Kuwait.

- Parliament moves to soon resolve the issue of stateless people. Some 100,000 stateless people, mainly Arabs, reside in Kuwait but are denied the freedom to travel abroad and benefit from some state services like higher eductaion.

- Parliament's Committee for the Protection of Public Funds advised the government on Monday to withhold its missile deal with Britain until parliament takes a decision. Earlier this year the defence ministry told parliament a decision to purchase British Aerospace Plc Sea Skua missiles was final.
- A five-year-old boy was kidnapped and raped by an unidentified man on Sunday morning.
